div.p: 1. V:15 Sunday.

With Mrs Adams, and our two Grand children I attended the morning service at St. John’s Church, where Mr Hawley read the prayers for the fourth Sunday after the Epiphany and Mra Missionary from the Diocese of Maryland, preached from Galatians 6.10. [“]As we have therefore opportunity, let us do good unto all men”—a very fervent and eloquent discourse, soliciting contributions, to sustain the Episcopal Church in Maryland— The preacher said he should not take up a collection now, but would visit the members of the Society in the course of the week— After Church I had visits from Mr M’Kean Buchanan from Philadelphia (who married Selina Roberdeau) and from Chief Justice Marshall, and Judge Story— Mr Buchanan comes to obtain permission from the Navy Department to go to the West Indies, for his health; being afflicted with a pulmonary complaint. Mrs Frye and her Son Thomas dined and spent the Evening here— After dinner I went to the Presbyterian Church, but finding there was no Service there, returned to St. John’s, and heard Mr Hawley read the Evening prayer and preach a short discourse from Luke 12.32 “Fear not, little flock; for it is your Father’s good pleasure to give you the kingdom.[”] Mr John Sergeant was at Church, and came home with me, and informed me of the election by the Legislature of Massachusetts, of the present Governor John Davis, to the Senate of the United States which he disapproved— He says Webster really thinks he shall be President— I read the first Sermon of a Volume by Dr Aaron Bancroft—entitled Religion in Man, a rational and voluntary service—and the second, an argument that Jesus Christ does not possess the attributes of Supreme Divinity. The volume contains 29 Sermons all controversial—unitarian, and perhaps universalist— I consumed much time in directing Orations to the Members of the Massachusetts Legislature

From this day forward the House are to meet at 11. O’Clock in the Morning— This was the day for receiving Memorials and Petitions; but Mr John Dickson one of the Members from the State of New-York, made a Speech of upwards of an hour in support of a petition signed by 816 ladies of the City of New-York for the abolition of Slavery and the Slave-trade in the District of Columbia—of which he moved the reference to a Select Committee, and that it should be printed— Chinn the Chairman of the Committee on the District of Columbia moved to lay the petition and the motion of reference on the table which was carried by yeas and nays 117 to 77.

M’Kay of North-Carolina moved a call on the Secretary of the Treasury, for a statement of all the monies expended within the last ten years upon the intercourse with the Barbary Powers—and a special Resolution of enquiry if any excess beyond 3000 dollars expended by any Consul on the Barbary Coast, for presents had been authorised by the Administration—lies over one day.

Hubbard from the Committee of Ways and Means, moved a call on the Secretary of War for information respected the present condition of the Delaware Breakwater to ascertain if it is expedient to make further Appropriations for that work. M’Carty’s Resolution as amended by the Committee on Indian Affairs, calling for voluminous documents from the President relating to the disposal of Reservations in Indian Treaties, produced a sharp altercation, between MCarty, and Lane another member from Indiana— Also between Lane, and Ewing, also a member from Indiana— C. C. Clay moved as a substitute to refer the subject to a Select Committee: upon which the yeas and nays were taken 22 to 172— The resolution finally passed; and the house adjourned—evening visit from Mr. Holmead the episcopal missionary from Maryland for a contribution

A Mr Smallwood came for a contribution to build a Presbyterian Church, in some town of Virginia— At the House, immediately after the Journal was read Mr Grennell moved for a call of the House observing that he regretted the Journal should have been read without a Quorum in the House— The Call of the House commenced, and about two thirds of the names were called; and a large Quorum answering the call was suspended Reports from Committees were received— Ferris of New-York offered a Resolution instructing the Committee of Ways and Means to inquire into the expediency of repealing the duty upon foreign Coal— He made an eloquent and pathetic speech for the relief of the poor inhabitants of the cities and cold climates—and said he thought there was nothing but the compromise against it; and had not much respect for that.— While he was speaking Crockett called for the Orders of the day, which prevailed 102 to 67.— The Speaker laid before the House, sundry Communications from the Executive Departments, and one from the Clerk of the House. Mr Bouldin’s motion to reconsider the vote rejecting the Bill making an Appropriation for the relief of the City of Alexandria, was taken up, and he made a speech urging the reconsideration— Chilton of Kentucky moved to lay the motion on the table. Mann of New-York called for the Yeas and Nays, which were 89 to 104 against laying on the table— Then the question of Reconsideration was debated by Thomas of Louisiana, Bates Speight, Vinton, Miller, Miner, Parks, Hawes, Mercer, Mann of New-York, Allen of Virginia—and Hardin rose to speak and offered to proceed or to wait till another day—he moved to adjourn which was carried by tellers 94 to 77— Bates, Briggs, Grennell and Phillips expressed themselves much dissatisfied with the late election of John Davis as a Senator of the United States, by the Legislature of Massachusetts— Bates said Davis had degraded his Office of Governor of the State by consenting to serve as a Senator— I was this Evening in addressing copies of my Oration, to persons here—
Wednesday 4. Feby 1835— Fahrenheit 14.—to 16.

Morning visits from Frederick Whittlesey and Gideon Hard; Antimasonic members of the House of Representatives— W. S. Smith called to ask for copies of the Oration on the life and character of La Fayette, of which I gave him twenty copies— In the House, Cambreleng from the Committee of Foreign Relations, reported a Bill for extending the Commission on the Claims upon France by the Treaty of 4 July 1831.— Love from the Committee on Indian Affairs, gave notice that they would take up the Western Territory Bill, next Tuesday— Dickinson moved a call of returns from the Secretary of War of monies expended yearly upon fortifications, and Mitchell of Ohio a call for contingent expenses of superintending the Cumberland road within the State of Ohio, and there were various propositions for establishing agencies in several of the States for the payment of pensions The Speaker presented to the house the annual and last Report of the Commissioners of the sinking fund— A bill from the Senate making an appropriation of five Millions of dollars for the satisfaction of claims of American Citizens on account of spoliations committed by the French, before the year 1800— Mann of New-York moved to lay the Bill on the Table— The Speaker said that was not in order—the motion must be to reject the Bill, for which he cited a Rule of the house— Mann had doubts of the rule but suffered the Bill to be read a second time and moved its reference to the Committee of Ways and Means—
VI. Thursday 5. Feby 1835— Fahrenheit 18 28.

The Potowmac river is again frozen over. At the Meeting of the House there being no Quorum a motion for a call of the House, and the yeas and nays were taken upon the call, but whe the clerk had gone through the roll call, the quorum had come in and the call was superseded— Foster chairman of the judiciary Committee reported a Bill to amend the judiciary system of the United States, which was twice read, and Foster moved it should be made the special order of the day for next Thursday— The Speaker thought the bill itself not in order, there being already another Bill on the same subject on the Calendar, reported by the judiciary Committee, the last Session— Foster then moved that the Committee of the whole on the Union should be discharged from further Consideration of the Bill of last Session, and its recommitment to the judiciary Committee. I asked him to name a longer day, for making the new Bill the special order; and that the bill be printed—he named next Monday week— Jarvis from the Committee on the Public buildings reported a Bill for building a fire-proof Treasury building, read twice and committed. Ferris of New-York, concluded a handsome Speech on the Resolution offered by him, looking to the repeal of the duty upon foreign Coal—after he finished the House passed to the orders of the day— Upon the motion of Patrick H. Pope, of Kentucky, all the orders were postponed to go into Committee upon the Louisville and Portland Canal Bill— This was much debated in Committee of the whole, and two others were reported to the house where Barringer moved to strike out the first section of the Bill—it was postponed to Monday next and the house adjourned soon after 3.— Governor Lincoln spoke to me, disapproving the Election of J. Davis to the U.S. Senate— Dr Kraitsir agent for the Poles called on me, and N. Frye brought me

The morning hour was consumed in debating a Resolution offered by Schley of Georgia to instruct the Committee of Post-offices and Post Roads to inquire into the expediency of abolishing the Office of Draftsman to this house (Stanberry) at the expiration of the hour the house passed to the orders of the day— The Speaker communicated to the House a Message from the President, with a Report from the Secretary of State, and extracts from despatches received from Edward Livingston, Minister in France, in answer to the call moved by me last
I moved that the Message and its enclosures should be printed, and referred to the
VII. Sunday 8. Feby 1835. Fahrenheit 0–10–4

A brisk Gale of wind the whole day, penetrating into every apartment in the House so that it was impossible to keep them comfortably warm, and almost disabling me from writing, at a moment when I had much to do, and when my disability distresses me deeply— I received by the mail many Letters, and among them one from Minott Thayer a Representative from Braintree in the Massachusetts Legislature, dated on Wednesday the 4th. at Noon and mentioning that the Senate of the State had sent to the House the name of J. Q. Adams as chosen on their part as a Senator of the United States— A Letter from B. F. Hallett of the same date confirms the statement—but the daily Advocate of the next morning, and a Postscript by my Son Charles to a Letter from his wife to his mother shew that the House would not confirm the choice of the Senate which was by a bare majority 21 votes, to 13 for John Davis—3. for I. C. Bates 3 for W. Baylies— Even this was totally unexpected— I went to the Presbyterian Church, and met Mr Butler the Attorney General at the gate there was no service there, and I came back to St. John’s Church where Mr Hawley read prayers for the fifth Sunday after the Epiphany, and preached from Philippians 3.7. [“]But what things were gain to me, these I counted loss for Christ 8. Yea doubtless, and I count all things but loss for the excellency of the knowledge of Christ Jesus my Lord: for whom I have suffered the loss of all things, and do count them but dung, that I may win Christ.” Mr Hawley gave notice that owing to the inclemency of the weather there would be no afternoon service— I read the 3d. and 4th Sermons of Dr Bancroft’s volume one maintaining the opinion that Jesus Christ was more than a man—and the other that he was less than God— Gales sent me Stansbury’s minutes of my remarks yesterday in the House, but they were very imperfect and it was impossible for me to revise them this day— I wrote to Mr Gales requesting him to postpone the publication of the debate.
VII. Monday 9. Feby 1835 Fahrenheit 0 14.
VII.15 Tuesday 10. Feby 1835— 12.
VII. Wednesday 11. Feby 1835. Fahrenheit 10 14.

At ten O’Clock I met in the room of the Committee of Ways and Means, the Select Committee on the Memorial from Philadelphia, for regulation of Weights and Measures— Present H. Binney, Chairman, Slade of Vermont, Moses Mason of Maine and myself— AbsentFerris of New-York— The Memorial was read, and some desultory Conversation followed, when the Chairman was requested to prepare a Report and then call the Committee together again— In the House Chinn, Chairman of the Committee on the District of Columbia, reported a Bill, for extending the Rail-road from Baltimore through the District to the City, which was read twice and after some discussion whether it should now be engrossed for the third reading, was postponed till next Monday— Gamble called up his Resolution, to call upon the Secretary of the Treasury for a plan for the keeping the disbursement of the public monies, without the agency of any bank Objection was made and Gamble moved the suspension of the rule, which was refused— Foster from the judiciary Committee reported a Bill for punishing the forgery of Consular Certificates and a Resolution to discharge the Committee from the further consideration of the part of the President’s annual Message relating to the extension of the Judiciary system, and of the Bill of the House to amend the judiciary system, there not being time to act upon the subject this Session— But Foster himself not agreeing with the majority of the Committee, moved to lay the Resolution on the table—after some debate the House passed to the order of the day.— Polk’s deposite Bank Bill was resumed and Robertson finished his Speech, in support of the motion to recommit the Bill, with the Instructions to report a project for dispensing with all agency of Banks— Cambreleng answered Robertson, whose motion was rejected— Ewing’s substitute Bill was then dismissed by yea and nays 1. to 189— Gordon’s Amendment was rejected 33 to 161— Then previous question, call of the House, till after 4 the motion to adjourn prevailed 95 to 85. Answer to judge Hopkinson—
V.15. Thursday 12. Feby 1835. Fahrenheit

The Revd. Mr Newell, brought me a Letter of recommendation from Mr Southard. He is a Mendicant Agent for Princeton College, the Alumni of which have resolved to raise one hundred thousand dollars, to endow the College, and for which they solicit the contributions of their friends. I declined subscribing for the present, having a similar demand pending, from the Alumni of Harvard University, and until that shall be determined, I did not incline to contribute for the benefit of other Colleges— I told Mr Newell that I had only two years since contributed to the establishment of a professorship at Princeton College—at the solicitation of Dr M’Dowell— At the House immediately after the reading of the Journal I obtained leave to present two Petitions from Citizens of the County of Oneida, in the State of New-York, for the abolition of Slavery in the District of Columbia— I referred to remarks I had made on presenting similar Petitions in December 1831—said I had not changed my opinions then expressed, and moved the reference of these Petitions without reading to the Committee on the District of Columbia, which was done. I then asked leave of the House to say a few words by way of explanation—which was granted— It was upon my having said last Saturday that the Senate had dodged the question of the dispute with France—and upon the commercial excitement produced by the stand taken by me on the same occasion— My explanation amused the House— The rest of the day was consumed in debating upon trifles— Whether next Tuesday or Friday should be assigned for Bills on the Territories, and the boundary of Ohio—whether Letcher and Moore should be paid for their travel and attendance here last Winter and finally what number of copies should be printed of the two Reports of the Post-Office Committee Majority and Minority which were made this morning— Yeas and Nays twice taken—3000 copies of the documents and 20000 copies of the two reports to be printed—

I attended public worship this Morning at the Presbyterian Church, where Mr Smith preached from Luke 17.10. [“]So likewise ye, when ye shall have done all those things which are commanded you, say, we are unprofitable servants, we have done that which was our duty to do.” Mr Smith gave notice that next Sunday morning the Revd Mr Armstrong an Agent of the board of foreign Missions, would preach for a contribution— The City of Washington is becoming absolutely the domain of a strolling Order of Friars Mendicant— Mr Walter S. Franklin, and Mr Jesse Miller the Clerk and a Member of the House of Representatives from Pennsylvania, with another Gentleman, a Stranger, were in my pew. I could not attend Church in the afternoon— Mr and Mrs Frye and their Son Thomas and Mrs W. S. Smith dined and spent the Evening with us. I read the 5th. Sermon of Dr Bancroft, upon the scriptural meaning of the terms, Holy Ghost, Holy Spirit, and Spirit of God—and the 6th upon the primitive state of the Christian Church— Much of my time is still absorbed in directing copies of my Oration on the life and character of La Fayette to two or three persons in each town of Massachusetts— I received this day a Letter, acknowledging the receipt of it from the Revd Andrew Bigelow, now Minister at Taunton—and for many days past I have received every day two or three Letters from Strangers requesting copies— This Evening I wrote a Sonnet, addressed to Miss Sarah Angelica Singleton, in the Album which Mr Lay purchased and gives her, at her request to procure for her something in my hand writing— Yesterday Morning I received information of the vote in the Senate of Massachusetts last Tuesday for Senator of the United States J. Q. Adams 25— John Davis 11. W. Baylies 3. and one Worcester County Senator absent— There are hints in the Newspapers of a Summer Session of the Legislature.

Stephen Phillips of Massachusetts presented a Memorial frommen, and 3600 Ladies of his District for the abolition of Slavery in the District of Columbia— After a few remarks he moved that without reading it should be laid on the table. Dickson of New-York then presented a similar Memorial from Rochester, in that State, and moved that it should be laid on the table and printed with the names— Boon of Indiana called for a division of the question— The motion for printing was agreed to, and then a question arose upon the printing of the names which led to a motion by Wise of Virginia, who had not voted on the order for printing was made for reconsideration of that vote, which gave rise to a snarling debate; the vote for reconsideration was carried by yeas, and nays, 125 to 81—and after sundry motions for the previous question, and others a motion to lay the Memorial and the motion to print on the table, was carried by yeas and nays—139 to 63— Denny presented two Memorials, one from Ladies for the same abolition of Slavery in the District of Columbia— Chinn from the Committee on the District of Columbia moved the assignment of next Saturday, for the consideration of Bills relating to the District, which was refused— Hawes asked leave to offer a Resolution to make the Post Office Reports the special order of the day next Monday: not allowed— Connor gave notice that he should ask the House to take up the Post-Office Bill next Wednesday— Wise from a select Committee offered a joint resolution to purchase 1000 copies of Sparks’s works of Washington which after debate was laid on the table— A Resolution reported by Jarvis from the Committee on the Public buildings for removing the Statue of Jefferson from the Rotunda was discussed till the House passed to the orders of the day— A joint Resolution, for a composition with Dibble for rejecting his project of a Potowmac bridge, was adopted; and a Bill for extending the Rail-road from Baltimore through the City passed to a 3d reading on the previous question moved by M’Kim adjourned about 4. O’Clock— Jarvis rode home with me.

Call at the War Department Office, with Letters ofHowe, Anthony Collamore,Ford, and J. L. Edwards’s Answer against the claim of Peter M’Intosh, for a Pension as an Artificer in the Revolutionary War— Mr Cass the Secretary of War took my papers, and promised me an order for the admission of Howe, as a Cadet at West Point next year, and asked for the Papers of M’Intosh, which I promised to furnish him— At the House, Chinn attempted to carry a motion to take up the District Bills next Saturday but failed. M’Kinley was equally unsuccessful, with his resolution for electing a Printer viva voce for the next House of Representatives, which he pressed two or three times upon the house, in vain— The Resolution reported by the Committee of Elections, to pay R. Letcher as a member of the House for the last Session of Congress, was discussed upon an amendment moved by B. Hardin, for equally paying T. P. Moore— Clay moved the previous question, but was not seconded, and Polk moved to pass to the orders of the day— A message from the President was received, with a Petition from a daughter of the Count de Grasse—referred to the Committee of foreign Relations— Watmough moved to postpone all the orders of the day to take up the Navy pay bill—upon which Polk called for the yeas and nays, and the vote was carried 110 to 103— The Bill was recommitted to a Committee of the whole, and there debated till past four, and reported to the house with amendments, and passed to be engrossed for a third reading by yeas and nays 102 to 82— Two amendments were moved against which I voted, and made a few remarks they were not carried— Adjourned shortly before 5.— Evening visit from Mr Ratcliff, whose memoir upon the project for making a Ship-canal across the Isthmus of Panama I had read, and told him I thought it well reasoned and well composed— I answered a Letter yesterday received from George Sullivan and employed the remainder of the Evening, in directing copies of my Oration.

Call at the Office of the War Department with the Papers of Peter M’Intosh, and I explained to him the claim as being in substance the same as that which he had decided last winter in favour of Solomon Thayer— He took the Papers and promised to examine them immediately to determine upon them— He spoke of the arrival from France, with intelligence of the reception there of the President’s Message; which it appears was very indignant. At the House Horace Everett presented certain Resolutions of the Legislature of Vermont, upon the subject of a National Bank the Public Lands and the late Usurpations of the Executive— In presenting them he mentioned them as only relating to the Public Lands; I called for the reading of the Resolutions and after they were read Turrell of New-York objected to their being printed— I called for the Yeas and Nays upon that question; upon which a debate arose, and continued till the expiration of the Hour, and Watmough called for the orders of the day— The Bill relating to the extension of the Rail-road from Baltimore was after some opposition, and a Speech from Parker of New-Jersey against it read a third time and passed— The Navy Pay bill then came up at the third reading— Crockett of Tennessee moved the Previous Question— Hardin of Kentucky was teeming with a Speech against the Bill, and asked Crockett to withdraw his motion, but he refused— Jarvis moved a Call of the House, which was pursued until 210 members answered— The motion for the previous question failed 82 to 90— Hardin then made his Speech about two hours against the Bill— Answered briefly by Wise and Lytle— Chilton then moved the previous question— Ward moved a call of the House which was refused by yeas and nays 101 to 103— The previous question was seconded 116 to 24— And the Bill passed by yeas and nays 117 to 102— The Bank deposit Bill was then taken up and Polk began a Speech for the reconsideration of the Amendment, adopted on Binney’s motion, but he soon gave way to a motion for adjournment about 4. O’Clock—

At the house, Chinn from the Committee on the District of Columbia moved a Resolution for assigning next Monday for the consideration of Bills, relating to the District, which was rejected— Gilmer from the Committee on Indian Affairs reported two bills concerning Indians, which were twice read and committed. Sutherland from the Committee of Commerce reported a Bill concerning the compensation of Custom House Officers, which was read twice committed to a Committee of the whole on the Union, and made the special order of the day for next Thursday— Hawes from the Committee of one member from each State on the West-Point Academy reported a Bill to modify the system of military Instruction there.

div.p: Hubbard from the Committee of Ways and Means reported a Bill authorizing the employment of additional Clerks in some of the Departments—twice read and committed— Sevier the delegate from Arkansas obtained a suspension of the Rules for the consideration of bills relating to the Territories— Four territorial bills were accordingly passed to the third reading— Connor, Chairman of the Committee of Post-Offices and Post roads moved to suspend all the orders of the day, to take up the annual Post-Office Bill, but at the suggestion of Vinton, and other members, varied his motion to an Evening Session at 6 O’Clock next Tuesday which was agreed to— Dunlap moved a suspension of the Rules to take up the Tennessee Land Bill, which failed— Gilmer moved to suspend the rules to take up the Bill for establishing the Western Territory, was carried by yeas and nays 145 to 50— The Bill had been reported last Session from the Committee of the whole with Amendments, which were adopted— I called for the reading of the Bill and it was read. I spoke against the Bill and moved to strike out the second Section, and gave notice that I should also move to strike out the third Section—this gave rise to a general debate on the Bill, till near five O’Clock— The Georgia Members and Hardin of Kentuckey supported the Bill—Burges, Archer, Vinton of Ohio opposed it— Hardin quoted the Act in 1804 for governing the Territory of Louisiana, and affirmed that I voted for it— I proved by reading from the Senate Journals of 1804 that I voted against it— The news from France was received that Serrurier, the French Minister here is recalled and Mr Livingston has been offered his Passports at Paris— It produced a strong Sensation was produced in the House, by them; and a motion was made that the House should adjourn, but it did not succeed.

This morning, with my wife and two Grand-children, I attended at St. John’s Church, where Mr Hawley read the prayers for Sexagesima Sunday and preached from 1. Chronicles 28.9. And thou, Solomon, my Son, know thou the God of thy father, and serve him with a perfect heart and with a willing mind: for the Lord searcheth all hearts, and understandeth all the imaginations of the thoughts: if thou seek him, he will be found of thee; but if thou forsake him, he will cast thee off forever.— After dinner, alone at the Presbyterian Church, I heard Mr Smith, from Romans 7:16—“If then I do that which I would not, I consent unto the Law, that it is good.” Neither of these Sermons had enough of my attention— Nor had the two Sermons which I read in Doctor Bancroft’s Volume. The 5th. on the Scriptural meaning of the terms Holy Ghost, Holy Spirit, and Spirit of God—and the 6th. on the primitive state of the Christian Church— I mistake it was the 7th. on the Ecclesiastical power and dominion gradually assumed by the Priesthood, and the 8th. on the Usurpation of the Bishop of Rome, that I read this Evening— Having read the others last Sunday— The remainder of this day was absorbed in writing upon the present state of our dispute with France, a subject upon which my anxious feelings have outstripped the necessity of the case. My apprehension is, not of War, but that the rights of the claimants under the Treaty, and the honour of the Country will on this subject be ultimately sacrificed and abandoned. The fear of this has urged me prematurely to press the consideration of it upon the House of Representatives, and now spurs me to renew the call upon them for action— I have failed, and the occasion has been seized successfully to turn the Election to the U.S. Senate against me, for what I have said in the House on this occasion— Cautious Perseverance! support me—
Monday 23. Feby 1835— Snow.

Rode to and from the Capitol. At the House, the motion for printing the Resolutions of the Legislature of Vermont, relating to the removal of the deposits, and to the Public Lands, was resumed— Slade called upon Beardsley for proof that there was in the Resolutions, any thing disrespectful to this House, as he had charged but was not answered— Boon of Indiana moved to lay the motion to print the Resolutions on the Table, upon which Horace Everett asked for the yeas and nays— The motion was rejected 32 to 139.— Boon disclaimed any disrespect to the Legislature of Vermont, but only wished to save time— Slade repeated his challenge to Beardsley to shew any thing disrespectful to this House in the Resolutions, without Answer— The motion to print, prevailed by yeas and nays—159 to 32— A number of petitions for the abolition of Slavery in the District of Columbia with a multitude of signatures were presented by sundry members, all without reading laid upon the table. Parker of New-Jersey presented Resolutions of the Legislature of New-Jersey against the U.S. Bank. Hubbard moved to suspend the rules to go into Committee of the whole on the Union, upon several Appropriation Bills.— The house went into Committee, M’Kennan in the Chair, and took up the Bill making appropriations for the Delaware Breakwater, for harbours and to remove obstructions from rivers, which was sometime debated, and to which many amendments were offered, and most of them rejected— The Bill for establishing a surveyor General in Illinois succeeded, to which Kinnard moved an amendment for a similar establishment in Indiana not adopted the Indian Annuity Bill came next and was read through without opposition some amendments proposed and adopted— The three Bills were reported to the House— Adjourned about 5. Jarvis rode home with me— I went into the Senate, and spoke to Mr Webster.— He agreed to act as one of the judges on the manuscripts upon a Congress of Nations, but said he should leave Washington immediately after the adjournment of Congress.

At the opening of the Session of the House Coll. Roger Jones called me out and enquired of me, my recollections respecting his nomination and appointment to promotion in 1827. and he gave me a pamphlet and some papers to refresh my memory on the subject, and said he would bring me others. R. M. Johnson from the Committee on Military Affairs moved, that one hour of tomorrow, for the consideration of four Bills, upon military Affairs— He also reported a joint Resolution, that General Scott’s system of discipline and Tactics prepared by General Scott by Resolution of the House of Representatives of 8. April 1834 be established for the Government of the army of the United States and of the Militia. Chinn from the Committee on the District of Columbia, moved to assign Thursday after one O’Clock, for Bills on the District—carried. Connor from the Post Office Committee reported a Resolution to continue to employ a person to make maps— Cave Johnson moved for the employment by the Clerk of the House of a translating Clerk at 800 dollars a year, which was carried— Beardsley from the Committee on the Judiciary reported the Bill from the Senate amendatory of the acts for punishing crimes—passed to a third reading— Committee of the whole on the Union Light House Bill taken up; and some other Bills— Snarling discussion between Burges and Pearce of Rhode Island upon Marine Hospitals at Newport or Providence— The House took a recess from four O’Clock to six— I wrote three Letters in the Chamber of the Committee of Manufactures, and despatched two of them— At 6. O’Clock P.M the House met again and went into Committee of the whole on the Union, upon the Bill for establishing new Post-Offices and Post-roads. Vance of Ohio in the Chair— Beardsley said the Post-master General was generous to a fault, and to almost more than a fault, which kindled a blaze against Barry— Wise enquired the meaning of the words— Bailie Peyton snarled with Beardsley, and W. Cost Johnson of Maryland, charged the whole Department was corrupt from head to foot—from the Post-master General down—fiery debate till 10. O’Clock when the Committee rose without reporting the Bill, and the house adjourned.

At ten O’Clock this morning I attended a Meeting of the select Committee on the memorial from Philadelphia concerning the standard of Weights and Measures, in the Committee room of the Committee of Ways and Means. All the members were present. H Binney Chairman, Murphy of Alabama, Slade of Vermont and Mason of Maine— Mr Binney read a Report which he had prepared, and a correspondence with the Secretary of the Treasury and F. Hassler— Voted that the Chairman do make the Report to the House and that Mr Murphy move that 5000 extra copies of the report be printed—

In the House, M’Kinley of Alabama, moved after some struggle with the rules of the House to get a majority vote by a mere majority, the suspension of the Rules to take up his Resolution for electing a Printer to the next Congress viva voce—his motion was rejected by yeas and nays 103 to 110. So he had even a majority against him— Gilmer obtained a suspension of the Rules to take up his joint Resolution for amending the Constitution of the United States in the Election of President and Vice-President of the United States. the object was to give the Election to the People—to limit the capability of Election to one term of four or six years, and to interdict the appointment of members of Congress to office under the Executive— Bailie Peyton announced Hugh Lawson White as a Candidate for the next Presidency; and attacked Polk for being opposed to him— Polk answered that he was responsible for his conduct to his Constituents— Pearce and Burges took ground against the Amendments in defence of the small States— The House adjourned after five O’Clock, and it was past six when I got home— There is to be a message of the President on French Affairs to-morrow.

Immediately after the Meeting of the House a Message was received from the President, with a Report from the Secretary of State, and a correspondence of E. Livingston with Admiral de Rigny— Letters from Livingston to the Secretary of State, and a correspondence between Forsyth, and the late French Minister Serrurier— I read them at the Speaker’s table— The day had been specially assigned for the consideration of Bills relating to the District of Columbia, and there was a debate of nearly two hours upon the question how the House should proceed to get a reading of the Message, which was moved for by Cambreleng they finally voted to postpone the business of the District for an hour to hear the Message— It was then read, and Cambreleng as Chairman of the Committee of Foreign Relations presented three Resolutions which he was authorized by a majority of the Committee to offer. Edward Everett then offered a minority Report, for three members of the Committee, which he moved to have received and considered with the Resolutions of Mr Cambreleng— I offered three Resolutions, as Amendments or substitutes of those offered by Cambreleng— After some debate the Message was referred to the Committee and Cambreleng’s Resolutions and mine and Everett’s Report were all withdrawn— The House then passed to the Consideration of the District business— Two or three insignificant bills went through a Committee of the whole, and were reported to the house and passed to be engrossed for the third reading— The Bill for Rechartering the District Banks was excluded from the list— The House adjourned just at 5. O’Clock— I took Jarvis home— As we passed down the avenue we saw John Ewing of Indiana, who had been violently assaulted, and cut with a bludgeon over the head by a Son of his Colleague Amos Lane, an Officer in the Army— Mary and her child Fanny both unwell—

In the house, H. Binney presented the Report from the Committee on Weights and Measures; and J. G. Watmough moved to print 3000 extra copies—which lies over one day. Hawes moved to suspend the rules, to have the Report of the West Point Academy printed—rejected by yeas and nays 70 to 189. Cambreleng made a Report from the Committee of Foreign Relations, with his three Resolutions, the same that he offered yesterday— Edward Everett then presented a Report from the Minority of the Committee—himself—Letcher and Coulter— I enquired whether the Minority Report concluded with any Resolution— Everett then answered no— I then offered my Resolutions as amendments or a substitution, and explained the cause of the difference between the copies of my Resolutions in the Globe and Intelligencer— Archer moved the reference to all to the Committee of the whole on the Union— Beardsley moved to strike out the reference to the Committee of the whole—and after debate the question was taken—by yeas and nays and announced by the Speaker as carried for Beardsley’s amendment 112 to 110— Miner of Connecticut said he had voted no and his name was recorded ay— It was found also that the ayes had been not 112 but 111— The vote then was announced 110. ayes 111 noes and Beardsley’s amendment was lost— Then Lytle who had voted no moved a reconsideration and it was refused 111 to 113.— Then the question was taken on the Reference to-morrow at 11. to the Committee of the whole on the Union and carried 116 to 107.— The house then proceeded the orders of the day— Sundry bills were discussed and about 5 O’Clock, Gilmer’s proposed Amendments to the Constitution as to the Election of the President and Vice-President. There was much manoeuvering to avoid the question upon the first of the Amendments, and after sundry motions to lay on the table, for the Previous Question, and for adjournment the House adjourned about 8 P.M— I walked home—over the Snow.

The House met at 10. O’Clock— Hawes from the Select Committee on the West-Point Academy, asked the consent of the House to offer a Resolution for printing 5000 copies of the Report of the Committee. objection made, Hawes moved to suspend the rule, refused. 72 to 98.— The motion to print 3000 copies of H. Binney’s Report on Weights and Measures was carried— Cambreleng moved to go into Committee of the whole on the Union, on the Controversy with France—carried— J. Y. Mason in the Chair. Cambreleng presented his three Resolutions; with a very few remarks— I made a motion that the first Resolution reported by him, and the first of mine substituted in its place, and spoke against his Resolution, in both its parts— Archer followed, objecting both to Cambrelengs Resolution and to mine—and offered a Resolution declaring it inexpedient for the House to act at all on the subject at this time—which he supported by a long Speech. He was followed by Pickens of South Carolina—on the same side— Patton, Read a Resolution which he had prepared differing from all the others, and supported his views by a speech— Bouldin of Virginia replied to Patton, Pickens, and Archer; who then offered to take Patton’s Resolution instead of mine, if I would do the same— I declined— Cambreleng in reply to all the debates offered to take the closing Sentence of the Report of the minority of the Committee of foreign Relations, as a Resolution instead of mine, and I agreed to accept it as a modification of mine— Burges spoke against the adoption of any Resolution— Coulter declared his willingness to vote for the Resolution as now proposed by Cambreleng. Chilton, proposed to strike out the words at all hazards which I declined— E. Everett moved first to take a recess—which failing—he moved the Committee should rise, which they did— The Speaker, read a Letter from J. Ewing, of Indiana, stating his inability to attend the House, owing to his having been assaulted by Lieutt. Lane son of Amos Lane, a member of the house, and an officer in the army— Hannegan moved the reference of the Letter to a select Committee of seven—to report the facts to the House, which after much debate and many cavilling questions was carried— Adjourned about 8 O’Clock— Walk home with Jarvis.
